I would like to what is the root cause of this issue? And if this is happening only with specific version? And also please help me in resolving this issue.

 

Thanks,

Srikanth

Show in explorer crashes

fields.description:
Have a developer who upgraded his SourceTree to 2.5.5. It states that the application could not be started because it requires .NET 4.7.1. Workstation has 4.7.2 installed so it appears that SourceTree isn't detecting the minor version update. I did the same update and had the same problem occur.

SourceTree was working on the previous version without issue.

!image-2018-05-03-12-43-49-890.png!
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't recognize .NET 4.7.2

fields.description:
I have a main branch called "master".

I also have a sub-branch thing, that I placed at "new_user/master"

When I change my branch to "new_user/master", then after the refresh, "master" is highlighted. This does not when I change to "new_user/john" - so it seems that because the name of the branch appear as "master" it is unable to highlight the correct one.
fields.summary: Highlighted branch changes to wrong branch when name is alike

fields.description:
Open a sub-repository in its own tab, and using the right-click context menu, choose "update to" a couple times and bounce around to 2 or 3 different commits within that sub-repository. 
Normally, since there aren't any uncommitted changes, this should just update to each revision without errors, no extra files, no merge conflicts, etc.

The operations described above work perfectly if the repository in question is NOT a subrepository (i.e. I was able to do a clone of the repository to a completely different folder on my hard drive and everything worked fine). I was also able to get it to work _in place_ (still linked as a subrepo) by using the windows bash command line (Windows-Subsystem-for-Linux with mercurial installed via apt-get). 

If, however, I use the gui to update between revisions (or type the gui command into the SourceTree terminal - embedded hg), It fails with a stream of errors (see the image below).

 

To summarize, it _doesn't_ work using SourceTree with embedded mercurial as long as it's a linked subrepository. The only way to get it to work properly is to bypass ST (and embedded hg) entirely, and use a different installation of mercurial operating directly on the same folder structure. You can get it to work within the sourcetree gui, but only if you're not working with a subrepository.
fields.summary: An "update" from one revision to another in a subrepository fails with unresolved changes.

fields.description: When toggled files between stage and unstage, the commit message I wrote will be changed or emptied by the software. It is annoying and frustrating! Please fix the bug, thanks! :)
fields.summary: Commit message cleared when I stage changed files

fields.description:
When merging and there are merge conflicts this will be shown in the commit message by default. After fixing these conflicts, committing is not possible.

I add a commit message, but the commit button is greyed out. After some time the commit message is reset to the conflict warnings and the commit button is available for a short time. This seems to be repeating infinite.

"Workaround" is to wait for the reset, replace the commit message fast and hit commit before it gets greyed out again.
fields.summary: Commit message resetted when merging
Abnormality in Japanese notation?

fields.description:
We have SAS developers who I am configuring to use Sourcetree to interact with our internal Git server.  These SAS developers do NOT have admin privileges to their laptops.  Also, we're in healthcare, so we have lots of layers of security here.  In order to install Sourcetree, we grant that user Admin privileges, install Sourcetree.  We have had to install an exception to our group policy in order for Sourcetree to start.  We also copy a shortcut to start Sourcetree (from C:/Users/<id>/AppData/Local/Sourcetree/Sourcetree.exe) to the users' desktop.  After this, the SAS developer is changed back to not have Admin privileges.  The user starts Sourcetree but the app never visualizes. 

When I start Sourcetree (I have admin privs), I notice that it downloads a couple of files and then starts.  I do not see these brief download dialogs when my SAS developer starts Sourcetree.  What are these files?  If a user does not have access to these external files, does Sourcetree just not start and not show an error message?  Is there a way to configure Sourcetree to not download these files?

Thanks!   Rick
fields.summary: Sourcetree won't start

fields.description:
I'm currently running SourceTree 2.4.7 on a system running Windows Pro 10 Version 1511.  As prompted by the notification icon on SourceTree, I tried to update to 2.5.5.  However, that version requires Windows .NET 4.7.1, which is not compatible with my version of Windows.

Now, the obvious answer for a private machine would be to update to a newer version of the OS.  However, this is machine is managed by our IT department (as would be the case with many of the users of SourceTree). Unless our IT department decides to push out an update, I'm stuck with that version.

Either a version that doesn't rely on the latest-and-greatest .NET would be useful, or at least a way to stop the automatic updates (as listed in issue SRCTREEWIN-2084).
fields.summary: Cannot Install 2.5.5 on Windows 10 1511

fields.description:
How to replicate:
 # Type message into commit window in the File Status tab.
 # Click on another program or window (either directly or using the taskbar)
 # Click on Sourcetree again.

When Sourcetree regains focus, it will refresh and erase the commit message. This happens every time, it is not intermittent.

If the user clicks on another tab (such as Log/History) after typing a commit message, Sourcetree will at this point store the message and prevent it from getting erased. Any further modifications to the message have to be protected the same way (by clicking a tab), or else the message will revert back to the state it was in the last time it was "saved" in this fashion.

It's ironic that I'm forced to write my commit messages in another app in order to prevent my source control software from deleting them.
fields.summary: Switching focus to another program/window and back to Sourcetree resets commit message

[https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/get-started/system-requirements]

fields.description:
Since very recently (I think it coincided with me updating to Sourcetree 2.5.5, but I'm not 100% sure), I've been periodically losing my commit messages while manipulating Sourcetree.


By "commit message" I mean the content of the edit box under "File Status" when you can describe your commit prior to committing it. In prior version this edit box was reliable and never lost unless closing the SourceTree application (which is fine). What happens now it that the content of this edit box sometimes gets reset to an earlier version of the text.

Possible hints as to what triggers it:
 * I think it tends to happen while I manipulate other elements of SourceTree. As the last major update of SourceTree (was it 2.0+?) changed the layout and made the File Status View section and the Log View mutually exclusive, I now often click back and forth to browse old commits for references while redacting my commit message.
 * I often use the "Amend to latest commit" option and as this option affects the edit box, it is possibly related.

I don't have a specific deterministic repro yet, I will try to make one and post it when I have one. *I wanted to post this early as from the user's point of view it has been _extremely_ frustrating as it essentially amounts to losing information.* Imagine typing a carefully thought out commit message and losing it.... For this reason I used a Symptom Severity of "Major", but I'm not sure what your preferred classification here.


Thank you!
Omar
fields.summary: Commit message periodically lost / reset to an earlier version

fields.description: While testing out BitBucket Cloud and Sourcetree for my organization, I'm using one account, part of a team with 5 members, and one project owned by the team. After installing Sourcetree and adding my BitBucket account, I can list the repos available in the "Remote repositories" section in the application. It shows the one repo as expected, but the "Clone" link doesn't do anything. Once I select the repo's row in the list (by clicking anywhere in the row except for the link), and then click the "Clone" link for that repo, it will work as expected.
fields.summary: Can't clone repo listed in account under "Remote repositories" unless row selected first

fields.description:
This is not a big deal, but I am slightly concerned about something that SourceTree is showing me after I perform and complete a Pull Request on a release branch.

The workflow that my team and I use is that we branch off of a Release branch, do our work, then perform a Pull Request to get it back into the Release branch. Rather typical.

The thing that is throwing me though is that after we do a Pull Request source tree doesn't show that the branches have merged back in visually. I don't think this is a big deal, but it makes me wonder if TFS isn't doing something or if SourceTree is the problem.

I have attached an example picture.
fields.summary: SourceTree Graph of branches don't merge after completed Pull Request
Sourcetree - User Can't Connect to Bitbucket - Insufficient authentication credentials

Restarting the application will do the trick.

fields.description:
After updating Sourcetree the old local app-2.5.x folders stay in the %APPDATA% folders. This seems to be an unecessary waste of space. In my current state after fresh install of 2.4.8 and then update to Sourcetree 2.5.5 the old folder AppData\Local\SourceTree\app-2.4.8 consumes 35 MB of disk space. 

With the current idea of making smaller updates and also forcing the user to regularly update Sourcetree the amount of old versions can quickly accumulate several hundreds of MB just dead space.

Is there any reason for the old app-x.y.z folders to remain in the %APPDATA% folder?

As far as I can think back with the Squirrel installer the old folders were never removed.
fields.summary: Old app folders app-2.5.x are not cleaned up after update of Sourcetree Windows

fields.description:

Current Sourcetree 2.5.5.0-beta0 folder names:
Still using SourceTree-Settings and SourceTree folders in %APPDATA% after rename to AppData\Local\SourceTreeBeta
AppData\Local\SourceTree-Settings

Current Sourcetree 2.5.5.0 folder names:
Still using SourceTree-Settings and SourceTree folders in %APPDATA% after rename to AppData\Local\SourceTree
fields.summary: Still using SourceTree-Settings and SourceTree folders in %APPDATA% after rename to Sourcetree

fields.description:
The order of open tabs or repositories is not stored after closing the application.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Start Sourctree with some repositories ( > 3) open or import them
2. Reorder according to your liking
3. Close Sourcetree
4. Open Sourcetree again and verify the order is the same as in step 3 when Sourcetree was closed

Analysis:
In the beta versions there is an XML file opentabs.xml in the SourceTree-Settings which contains the order in which the tabs seem to be reopened. Although the file is written everytime Sourcetree is closed not the order in which the tabs were left when closing is saved. 

Just out of curiosity:
When changing the order in the XML file the order of the tabs are opened in the correct order after Sourctree is started.
fields.summary: Sourcetree does not save the opened tabs / repository order when closed

fields.description:
Git 2.5 come with a new command worktree:
https://git-scm.com/docs/git-worktree

You can use it to manage multiple working trees attached to the same repository.
It is very useful when working on large project with multiple working branches.
Hope GitUp can support this wonderful new feature.

There are some discussion on other git client libraries introducing worktree support:
* https://github.com/github/hub/pull/970
* https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-143404
fields.summary: Add git 2.5 `worktree` command support  [This issue should be moved to SourceTree for Windows]

One of these 3 updates is necessary to install the .NET Framework 4.7+ which is necessary to run SourceTree v2.5.5.

SourceTree should check if the dependencies for the next version can be fulfilled before proposing to update to an unusable version requiring a reinstall.

fields.description:
Creating this issue on the advice of @AskAtlassian on Twitter.

 

Steps to reproduce:
 # Right-click branch, select "Create pull request".
 # Message shows up

Steps to workaround:
 # From the message box, click "Settings"
 # Click the configured remote (in my "origin")
 # Click "Edit"
 # Do not make any changes.
 # Click OK.
 # Try to create a pull request again - everything is now OK until the next reboot.

I notice that even between restarts of SourceTree it's OK, but once I reboot the system it needs me to perform the same workaround. If I select a different repository, I have to repeat the same workaround but then it's OK until I reboot.

I've uploaded a video of the issue here: https://youtu.be/H-tSCdXEg2Y
fields.summary: Trying to create a pull request shows "You don't have any remotes which ...", easily resolved by opening edit and clicking OK

fields.description:
Click on a branch. Then click back on working copy. Try that a few times.

The main view is supposed to update respectively. For me, this update stops after just a few clicks and I always have to restart SourceTree.

Since the switch is kind of slow to begin with, I suspect it is crashing like crazy in the background. Also, this has been going for quite some time over many released versions.
fields.summary: Main view stop updating

fields.description: With 2.5.5.0 update there are Pull and Push buttons switched - Pull is on the left, Push in the middle (and tech on the right). Push should be on the left, Pull in the middle.
fields.summary: Push and Pull button position switched

fields.description:
So I've saw already a similar ISSUE, but now with 2.x.x versions the app asks credentials frequently...

...and login to github was impossible.

I was trying to delete/restart/re-add user credentials via: Sourcetree > Tools > Options > Authentication - although here the username/pwd was accepted, still no luck with push, sourcetree asked my pwd again and again...
 

Then i've also found this: C:\Users\USERNAME\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\accounts.json
Once removing the github related save from here:

1) the push asked me for credentials (new look, big cca. 480x480 dialog) - they've failed
2) then again got a new window for entering credentials (old look, cca. 200x480 dialog) - which succeeded
3) push also succeeded

So this one helped, but the overall user experience is very poor. There's a mess around that authentication and pwd saving.
fields.summary: Github auth. issues - with workaround

fields.description:
При введении символа двойной кавычки " (переключиться на английский язык и нажать Shift+Э (код ASCII 34)) перед числом и последующей отправки формы - поля калькулятора очистятся, а в результате скидки будут нули.

 

*Steps To Reproduce:*
 # Зайти на сайт [http://www.nibulon.com/data/zakupivlya-silgospprodukcii/kalkulyator-znizhok.html]
 # В поле "Виберіть культуру:" выбрать любое значение
 # В поле "Виберіть базис поставки:" выбрать любое значение
 # В поле "Виберіть показник вологості, %:" ввести двойную кавычку " и затем любое число
 # В поле "Виберіть показник сміттєвої домішки, %" ввести двойную кавычку " и затем любое число
 # Нажать кнопку [Розрахувати]

 

*Expected result:* Вывести сообщение об ошибке с текстом "Заборонено вводити спецсимволи в поля для вводу"

 

*Actual result:* поля "Виберіть показник вологості, %:" и "Виберіть показник сміттєвої домішки, %:" очистились, а поля скидок приняли вид "Знижка по вологості - 0,00%, 0,00 грн. Знижка по засміченості - 0,00%, 0,00 грн."

fields.description: When I installed sourcetree, you used to install it like any other program. Now you have to have an account to install it. This is a downgrade. Now you have to be online to install the program and you have to create yet another account to forget about, or give out more of your google data to yet another 3rd party. It would be better if we could go back to the days when you didn't need an account to install the software.
fields.summary: Go back to installing without an account

fields.description: Installer hangs.  It is not possible to do recommended changes to IE settings. These are controlled by administrator.  Please fix this, you have a very bad logic in the installer.
fields.summary: Unable to install Sourcetree on remote machine

fields.description:
In File Status page frame, when typing a text for a commit, typing text and moving cursor with arrows is really slow.
When opening the Task manager, i can see than SourceTree.exe process time increases to 25% (a full CPU)
fields.summary: Slowdowns when typing commit text

fields.description:
I have recorded a video of what's happening. This happens even if I restart sourcetree and my computer beforehand and has been present for weeks. I should clarify that in the video, I only ever click the "Stage Selected" and "Unstage Selected" buttons even though I hover over the All button for a time. 

The issue is also present when dragging a file into staged files.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=858bZeyGMwk]

 

It's a real ballache to have to unstage that folder every single time I want to commit.
fields.summary: 'Stage Selected' stages unwanted files

fields.description:
It would be glad to find files in index/working directory view search box by directories as SourceTree for mac and the past version of SourceTree for windows worked.

ex.
 path/to/target/files/text.txt
 I want to get the text.txt file by searching with word "files".
fields.summary: searching files by directories

fields.description:
I noticed this behavior a long time ago when sourcetree upgraded to 2.4.x. I downgraded to 2.3 and the problem is gone. Recently I tried the newer 2.4.8, the problem is still there.

 

The UI will keep refreshing the "push changes immediately" line, and there are many, many processes in process viewer. I recorded the video of refreshing, saved the log.

 

Note the UI above don't have the commit history shown. If I clicked the master branch, the history will be shown in window and the refreshing stopped. I think sourcetree was trying to update the status, but the UI is in a wrong mode that keep asking to update status.
fields.summary: The UI keep refreshing with lots of background tasks

fields.description: The ability to update work items in VSTS with the associated commit.  Whether this is achieved through issue SRCTREEWIN-7028 or some other means.
fields.summary: VSTS Work item integration

fields.description: Repository search do not work anymore
fields.summary: Repository search do not work anymore

fields.description: When I use a format like "hotfix/zz/bugfix_12" to name the branch, SourceTree Gitflow does not show bugfix branch
fields.summary: SourceTree Gitflow does not show bugfix branch.

fields.description: When I use a format like "hotfix/zz/bugfix_12" to name the branch, SourceTree Gitflow does not show bugfix branch
fields.summary: SourceTree Gitflow does not show bugfix branch

fields.description:
The new MSI installation always uses system Git installation and no longer provides an embedded Git installation, but it still asks to download embedded git-lfs everytime a repository containing lfs tracked files is opened. Sourcetree never should ask to download embedded git-lfs if System Git is used and LFS is available there.

System Git is 2.17.0 with bundled git-lfs 2.4.0
fields.summary: Disable lfs download for MSI installations

fields.description:
Sometimes, when trying to commit, on the File Status page frame, the "Push changes immediatly to..." begins to quickly blink continuously, causing the commit nearly impossible because the UI is unresponsive.
When clicking several tiles on the commit button, commit is occuring finally, but UI remains unresponsive for some time.
After UI comes back again, Log / History page frame is presented with empty content.
After some time, everything comes back to normal, but slowly...
fields.summary: Unresponsive UI when commiting

fields.description:
It would be very useful to be able to quickly open a commit (from log/history) on Bitbucket in a browser or have a link for it.

Given that SourceTree is also an Atlaassian product it's surprising that there is no such feature (or it's very well hidden).

I'm sure there is a way to make a custom script by finding the .git folder and determining the repo's Bitbucket URL from a corresponding Bitbucket remote. But I think this deserves to be a part of SourceTree itself. Feel free to close this feature request if you think otherwise.
fields.summary: Open commit on bitbucket

fields.description:
It would be awesome if it was possible to change the way that the commit details and diff are organized in the SourceTree window.

 

Right now the details view is split between commit message, files and so on (on the left side) and diff (on the right). But it would be more convenient for some people to have a wider diff area taking up the whole width. I think the main details and diff could be stacked horizontally or maybe the details view could be merged with the history view. If these panels could be dragged and dropped dynamically like in some IDEs that would make it very flexible.
fields.summary: Option to change layout of diff and commit message (give more space to diff)

fields.description:
Sometimes my SourceTree generates high CPU load. When this occurs, the application is in "File Status" view, and the "Push changes immediately..." checkbox is blinking. I've tried disable "Refresh automatically when files change" and "Refresh when application is not in focus" options, without success.

However the issue appears regularly, unfortunately I was not able to reproduce intentionally.

I am using SourceTree alongside Visual Studio 2017.

I attached a log exported when the issue occurred.
fields.summary: High CPU load

fields.description:
Since the latest upgrade I noticed Pull and Push have changed order. At first I thought it was my imagination, but I kept automatically going to where I expected one button to be and then it was the other.

I checked with a colleague who hasn't upgraded yet and sure enough his are in the other order.

If you're going to keep this new order, could you please add a way for users to configure it? I have become accustomed to using Sourcetree on a daily basis, and this disrupts my flow every time.

I can see how this change might provide a more intuitive order of buttons for new users, but it's quite disruptive to existing users.
fields.summary: Pull/Push button order switched with no way to change back

fields.description:
After running in the background for an hour or more, SourceTree sporadically consumes high amounts of CPU.

The checkbox 'Push changes immediately' within the commit section flashes indicating the UI is being continually refreshed.

I have tried disabling the settings `Refresh automatically when files change` & `Refresh when application is not in focus` but the bug still occurs. It also happens on a colleagues machine with the same environment.
fields.summary: High CPU usage likely caused by continuous UI refresh

fields.description: Sourcetree should only apply --progress to checkouts when git >= 2.7.0
fields.summary: The Git  --progress option on checkout is not supported in Git < 2.7.0

fields.description:
What title says, I opened the dialog to create a new branch and I am hit in the face by the red text complaining that the name field is empty. I know it's empty, I just opened the dialog... It's breaking my attention because it's so red, I thought something bad happened.

It's enough the button is disabled, the red punch in the face is too much!

!image-2018-04-13-11-17-09-688.png!
fields.summary: New branch dialog displays error at start

fields.description: Please check this screenshot.
fields.summary: Git Version Label "Mercurial"

fields.description:
Searching for repositories under Remote does not work correctly. When you search it refreshes the list, but the returned result look like it just reshuffle the order. Example: I have one repository called validation, and when I enter validation in the search this is what is being returned:

!Sourcetree.png!

The expected result is that is should only list the validation repository.
fields.summary: Searching remote repositories is not working

fields.description:
Under remote, the list of available repositories are not listing all, by the looks of it leaves out the first repository from every project in Bitbucket. 

Here is the list of available repositories in the AI project in Bitbucket

!Bitbucket.png!

This is what Sourcetree is showing

!Sourcetree remotes.png|width=1104,height=347!

Notice that the AirScan repository is missing from the list.
fields.summary: Remote repositories are not listing all repositories

fields.description:
In the repository settings tab, it is possible to add extended integration settings, which can be used for e.g. pull-requests. Each time the application is restarted, the settings that were inserted dissapear and you need to be re-applied.

This problem is recurrent since some versions. I believe I have this since I use version 2 of SourceTree.

We use the 'Stash' version of the extended, and it is really helpful for Pull-requests, it's just a PITA that we need to re-apply the information each time we start-up the program.
fields.summary: Extended integration settings on repository settings aren't stored

fields.description:
I have setup gpg signing using sourcetree but cannot commit anything via sourcetree as I get the below error.  it works perfectly from git bash and other git tools.

I have also noticed that my *pubring.kbx* file exists in *%appdata%/gnupg/pubring.kbx* but Sourcetree is prefixing the path to my repo before it, why?! How do I change that?

{noformat}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false commit -q -F C:\Users\RD\AppData\Local\Temp\mrso10yh.pxh
gpg: keyblock resource 'C:/PATH_TO_REPOSITORY/%appdata%/gnupg/pubring.kbx': No such file or directory
gpg: skipped "XXXXXX": No secret key
gpg: signing failed: No secret key
error: gpg failed to sign the data
fatal: failed to write commit object
Completed with errors, see above.
 {noformat}
fields.summary: Cannot sign commits

fields.description:
"Log Selected" is sometimes incorrectly disabled.
 # Select File Status: Working Copy
 # Set Show Only: All files, sorted by file name
 # Enter a valid search filter
 # Right-click on any Unstaged File, "Log Selected" is enabled. Select this and close report.
 # (Right-clicking on other Unstaged Files at this point also has "Log Selected" enabled.
 # Enter a new search filter.
 # Right-click on any Unstaged File, "Log Selected" is disabled.
 # (Re-entering the original search filter and re-selecting previously selected file will also have "Log Selected" disabled.
 # Close/reopen SourceTree.
 # Retry operation, "Log Selected" now available for initial search again.

I user "Log Selected" frequently for trying to poke around for files that may have changed while trying to determine when a bug was introduced to an area, so it is rather annoying to have to close/reopen SourceTree every time I want to perform a new file search.
fields.summary: Log Selected disabled for Working Copy files after second search

fields.description: I have tried doing a clean uninstall/reinstall, and I am still getting this issue. It only happens in one of my Repos. Friday I had a list including master, and other branches, and now they are all gone, and when I create new ones they don't show up. This error is impeding me from completing any work. I have attached a screen shot of the app not giving me access to the dropdown under the branches tab.
fields.summary: All local Branches and the ability to switch between them has disappeared.

fields.description:
Suppose I click "Discard Hunk" button. It shows a popup box asking for confirmation.

In such boxes, I have habit of using space to press enter (since it's close to my left hand).

Native Windows dialog box support this feature by default. It would be awesome if Sourcetree can fix it too.
fields.summary: Use space for enter in alert boxes

fields.description:
SourceTree keep crashing when switch to 'log view'.

Circumstances which switch to 'log view'

1. After source tree startup, I double click open a bookmarked repository.

2. After commit stage change.

 

Problem signature:

Problem Event Name: APPCRASH 

Application Name: SourceTree.exe 

Application Version: 2.4.8.0 

Application Timestamp: 5a5f7807 

Fault Module Name: clr.dll 

Fault Module Version: 4.6.81.0 

Fault Module Timestamp: 5584e818 

Exception Code: c0000005 

Exception Offset: 00000000005ac048 

OS Version: 6.2.9200.2.0.0.768.100 

Locale ID: 17417 

Additional Information 1: 46fe 

Additional Information 2: 46fea8ab09c611f979c65e39da4a0672 

Additional Information 3: faef 

Additional Information 4: faef95ba0f6f655e4e42673027b6c3c9
fields.summary: SourceTree version 2.4.8.0 crash on opening repository or after commit  ( 'log view' )

fields.description:
# Run SourceTree with at least three unstaged files (like in the attached screenshot).
 # Select any middle unstaged file (any file except the first or last files).
 # Run the "External Diff" action with keyboard short-cut, Ctrl-D.
 # Close the external diff program (I use WinMerge).
 # Select the next unstaged file with the down arrow key on the keyboard.
 # Notice the selection always jumps back to the top.

This is annoying because I usually diff files one at a time, from first to last. It would be nice if SourceTree kept track of my last selected file. This is so that I only need to press the down key once to select the next file to diff.

Note that the selected file stays the same after I close WinMerge. But instead of moving the selection down when I press the down array key, the selection resets back to the top.
fields.summary: External Diff always resets the next file selected with keyboard to be the first one

fields.description:
Would be please possible to add tooltip with information about tracked branch when mouse is hovering over local branch name in list of local branches?

 

Thank you.

 

PS: This is copy of issue #SRCTREE-5584 in Sourcetree for Mac project-
fields.summary: Show tracked branch as tooltip on branch
Custom Action Edit Windows is cutting the OK and Cancel buttons

fields.description: It would be nice to have an option to auto wrap text in diff views. This would be a great feature for everyone who uses SourceTree as a revision control system for his text files like articles, theses etc. Otherwise you have to scroll horizontally if your line (sentence) is to long for your diff view.
fields.summary: word wrap for diff views

fields.description:
The connection to my remote in Bitbucket uses the SSH protocol. Using Sourcetree to push, pull, and fetch works as expected and without issues.

The problem occurs when I start Git Bash using the Terminal button in Sourcetree. If I try to use any of the remote-related commands like `git push`, `git pull`, or `git fetch` then I get prompted for my key's passphrase. The annoying part is that this happens every time I use any of those commands, regardless of whether I am still in the same Git Bash session, or if the Git Bash window was closed and reopened, or if I used the command only a few seconds ago.

I would understand if the key is loaded — and I get asked for the passphrase — the first time I use a remote-related command for that session of Git Bash, but if I don't close the Git Bash window, being asked for the passphrase for every command is bothersome. Is it possible to keep the key loaded for that session of Git Bash?

PS: I've been able to associate Sourcetree's ssh-agent with a Git Bash session, and keeping the key loaded, but only if the Git Bash window wasn't started from the Terminal button in Sourcetree. I do this by manually (or with a script) setting the SSH_AUTH_SOCK and SSH_AGENT_PID variables accordingly. But for some reason, this doesn't work if I try to do it with the Git Bash session started with the Sourcetree Terminal button.
fields.summary: SSH-Agent is not available from Git-Bash terminal
Add SortBy file type option when we are commiting changes
Checkbox on dialog seen before external merge should not permanently cancel external merge

fields.description:
"Unstage hunk" button does not work for renamed file.

("unstage selected lines" works fine,

  and  "unstage hunk" for not renamed file also works fine.)

 

reproduce:
 # commit any file to git
 # rename committed file and modify small part of contents
 # stage file
 # select staged file (icon should be "R")
 # push "unstage hunk"   =>  nothing happens
fields.summary: Unstage hunk not working for renamed file

fields.description:
There was an argument injection vulnerability in Sourcetree for Windows via Mercurial repository tag name that is going to be deleted. An attacker with permission to create a tag on a Mercurial repository linked in Sourcetree for Windows is able to exploit this issue to gain code execution on the system.


*Affected versions:*
* All versions of SourceTree for Windows before version 2.5.5.0

*Fix:*
* Upgrade SourceTree for Windows to version 2.5.5.0 or higher from https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/

*Acknowledgements*
Atlassian would like to credit Zhang Tianqi @ Tophant for reporting this issue to us.

For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/ERyUO].
fields.summary: Argument injection via Mercurial tag names on Windows - CVE-2018-5226

fields.description:
Sometimes, and I'm sorry I can't be more specific about when this occurs, the diff panel will start failing to update when selecting different files in the log view. It will just continually show the rotating logo, and show the original file diff.
Swapping repositories will show the originally selected file diff for that repository, still with the rotating logo.
Nothing I do will recover from this except exiting and restarting SourceTree.
fields.summary: Diff panel not updating correctly

fields.description: It happens on 4 PCs separately installed.
fields.summary: Sourcetree crashed after click the + tab

fields.description:
I enabled the fixed-width font and column guideline display at 50 characters and restated Sourcetree. Then, I added the following 50 character string to the commit box:

01234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789

However, as shown in the attached screenshot, the guideline sits before the final 7, three characters earlier than specified.
fields.summary: Column guideline ends 3 characters early

fields.description:
Hi, we have an issue with the lfs integration in sourcetree. We are working on different branches and when a new lfs file is pushed on a different branch than the current, it become impossible to merge that one.

 
{code:java}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false merge origin/master origin/HEAD
Updating 0c81946d0..ff37c34f7
Downloading resources/gfx/Game/Common/Crystal_Generator/SPR_Crystal_Ge.png (382.58 KB)
Error downloading object: resources/gfx/Game/Common/Crystal_Generator/SPR_Crystal_Ge.png (2c6fd1946b07f1799ee9301be00c3d6a617a975ac19a2152c1193b5785f567c7)
Errors logged to F:\wks_Inferno\Inferno\.git\lfs\objects\logs\20180328T154957.5621179.log
Use `git lfs logs last` to view the log.

error: external filter 'git-lfs filter-process' failed
fatal: resources/gfx/Game/Common/Crystal_Generator/SPR_Crystal_Ge.png: smudge filter lfs failed
Completed with errors, see above.
{code}
 

 

The problem seems to be fixed when we execute the "git lfs fetch --all" or "git lfs fetch --recent" manually in the command window.

 

PS: note than we used the embebbed git v2.15.1 - lfs v2.0.2
fields.summary: LFS integration issue

fields.description:
If the selected commit in the commit list doesn't have any changes associated with it (an empty commit), then it will show the diff of the previous non-empty commit.

Oddly, the empty commit goes back to showing nothing if the previous diff was for unstaged changes.
fields.summary: Empty commits retain the diff from the previous non-empty commit viewed

fields.description:
Creating a pull request function causes SourceTree to perform a git push instead without even getting approval from remote first:

!PR1.JPG|thumbnail!

After closing the git push output window, SourceTree opens up the remote site (I'm using Stash), and now states that there's a conflict (because the commit was pushed up already):

!PR2.JPG|thumbnail!

If "Create pull request" for SourceTree is meant to be a git push instead of requesting remote to pull, then it defeats the purpose of calling it a pull request.
fields.summary: "Create pull request..." button performs an immediate git push instead of creating a request for remote repository to approve and pull.

fields.description:
I created a hotfix, did some  stuff, commited and clicked finish hotfix.

I get asked if I want to add a tag which shows up as the hotfix's name at the moment, I write "2.0.3" in the textfield next to the tag button. I finish the hotfix. and the tag is ignored, my tag of "2.0.3" is no where to be seen and the hotfix is tagged with the name of the hotfix.
fields.summary: After finishing a hotfix your custom tag is ignored
